items.synopsis: There are calls for Queensland to follow Victoria's lead, which reduced its shooting deaths with a focus on de-escalation of conflict and avoiding or minimising police use of force.

title.children: Queensland Police shot more people than officers in rest of Australia combined last year

items.synopsis: China agrees to drop 80 per cent tariffs on Australian barley, after a long-running and high-profile trade war between the two nations.

title.children: Australia gains trade victory as Chinese barley tariffs lift

image.altText: ACT Director of Public Prosecutions Shane Drumgold.

title.children: ACT government bows to pressure and will release report into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution next week

image.altText: A man in a lime green suit jacket with red details gestures to a large table of Beatles merchandise.

title.children: Money can't buy me love: Beatles super fan to sell his massive memorabilia collection

title.children: 69yo woman jailed for killing abusive husband with spiked vegetable soup

items.synopsis: Winter temperatures have neared 40 degrees Celsius in parts of South America, which is up to 20C higher than normal for this time of year and the equivalent of Sydney hitting 35C in the first week of August.

title.children: Mid-winter temperatures in South America rival those of the baking northern hemisphere summer

items.synopsis: Alan Charles Jones walks free from court in Albany despite being convicted of sexually abusing a boy 40 years ago.

title.children: Elderly child sex offender avoids jail over historical offences in country WA

image.altText: A woman taking a selfie

items.synopsis: A 34-year-old woman on bail for her alleged role in a 2021 murder has asked the Supreme Court to send her back to prison because of the "daily battle just trying to find suitable accommodation".

title.children: Woman on bail unable to find housing asks court to send her back to jail, judge agrees

image.altText: Two women walking and smiling next to a large flag displaying the Commonwealth Games Federation logo

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Prime minister says date of Voice referendum won't be revealed tomorrow — The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong and Minister for Trade Don Farrell have welcomed the drop of 80 per cent tarriffs China had on Australian Barely. The sanctions on barely trade will be lifted from tomorrow. "It's the right outcome for Australian producers and Chinese cosumers," Senator Wong says. "It affirms the calm and consistent approach the Albanese government has taken." Senator Farrell says since May 2020, China’s duties on Australian barley have effectively blocked exports to that market, worth about $1 billion. "Our barely growers and exporters will now be able to reenter tariff free the Chinese market it's another very positive step in the full resumption of normal trade between Australia and China," he said. The Trade minister says he's hopeful this is a positive step toward resolving all trade disuptes with China.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Drop of barley tariffs affirms 'calm and consistent' approach government has taken, says Penny Wong

props.alt: A woman in a press room in adelaid with australia and torres strait flags visible. She has short grey hair and red blazer on

children.content: (ABC News)
Foreign Minister Penny Wong and Minister for Trade Don Farrell have welcomed the drop of 80 per cent tarriffs China had on Australian Barely.
The sanctions on barely trade will be lifted from tomorrow.
"It's the right outcome for Australian producers and Chinese cosumers," Senator Wong says.
"It affirms the calm and consistent approach the Albanese government has taken."
Senator Farrell says
since May 2020, China’s duties on Australian barley have effectively blocked exports to that market, worth about $1 billion.

"Our barely growers and exporters will now be able to reenter tariff free the Chinese market it's another very positive step in the full resumption of normal trade between Australia and China," he said.
The Trade minister says he's hopeful this is a positive step toward resolving all trade disuptes with China.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Anthony Albanese has told media at the Garma Festival he will not announce the Voice referendum date tomorrow, as previously predicted. "We will announce though a date for the referendum at an appropriate time after consultation as well," he says. "One of the things I will be doing this weekend is speaking with people here as I have around the country respectfully about their view of the day." Alabanese says now is the time for Australia to have a Voice to Parliament. "If not now, when?" he says. "We are the only former colony of Europe that does not recognise that there were inhabitants here before 1788, in our case."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prime Minister confirms date of Voice referendum won't be revealed tomorrow

children.content: Anthony Albanese has told media at the Garma Festival he will not announce the Voice referendum date tomorrow, as previously predicted.
"We will announce though a date for the referendum at an appropriate time after consultation as well," he says.
"One of the things I will be doing this weekend is speaking with people here as I have around the country respectfully about their view of the day."
Alabanese says now is the time for Australia to have a Voice to Parliament.
"If not now, when?" he says.
"We are the only former colony of Europe that does not recognise that there were inhabitants here before 1788, in our case."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In an announcement at the Garma Festival, Anthony Albanese has confirmed a commitment of $6.4 million to develop a Garma Institute for tertiary education in North East Arnhem Land. "We know the vision for on-country learning for younger people, from early childhood education to university, is something so important," he says. "We know it works. The local schools are a success. The school attendance rates shows what works for them." Albanese says the institute will ensure people can stay on country and continue study among their community.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prime Minister confirms tertiary institution in North East Arnhem Land

props.alt: Anthony albanese in a pink shirt fronts the media

children.content: (ABC News)
In an announcement at the Garma Festival, Anthony Albanese has confirmed a commitment of
$6.4 million to develop a Garma Institute for tertiary education
in North East Arnhem Land.
"We know the vision for on-country learning for younger people, from early childhood education to university, is something so important," he says.
"We know it works. The local schools are a success. The school attendance rates shows what works for them."
Albanese says the institute will ensure people can stay on country and continue study among their community.
